comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The Linenhall Barracks was located on Linenhall Street just off Bolton Street in Dublin.  One of the great and unsung battles of 1916 took place nearby and involved troops stationed in the Linenhall.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Unless it has changed drastically in recent years just a part of it was used for flats.  Part (using the entrance gate) was used as the Apprentice Training School for Bolton Street College for many years.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Glad to hear you say "unsung" as I was feeling a bit ashamed that I had never heard of it!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
Troops from Linenhall Barracks who wanted to go to the aid of their comrades in the other parts of Dublin were pinned down by rifle fire from the Pub on the north corner of North King Street and Church St junction.  It was known as Reilly's Fort for many years right up into the 70's.  It was higher than other buildings around and the rebels had a great lookout over Nth King St and the surrounding area.  They pinned the soldiers down and eventually the troops had to work their way down from house to house to get close enough to engage the rebels from cover.  Legend has it that on the way they executed some local men who were trapped in their houses by the crossfire.  Reilly's Fort was one of the last places to surrender and had inflicted proportionately more casualties that almost any other outpost.  The only plaque on the wall of the building up to quite recently was to commemorate Kevin Barry who was arrested later in nearby Coleraine St.
When I worked in the area in the late 60's and 70's there were still families whose fathers/uncles had died in the fighting!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: In the 1901 census it seems to have been residential. e.g. www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1901/Dublin/Inns_Qua... Edit: I say residential - it actually seems to have been a tenement: www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1901/Dublin/Inns_Qua...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: This pic seems familiar: www.easter1916.ie/index.php/places/a-z/linenhall-barracks/

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Using the power of Google I have just found that the local anecdotes were a bit off on detail and understated the extent of the fighting.  A total of 14 men who had no part in the fighting were shot dead by the troops as they advanced behind an armoured car along Nth King St.  General Maxwell admitted as much later and an enquiry was set up but found nobody was to blame!  The fighting was extensive and injured rebels were treated in the nearby Father Mathew Hall.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Niall, looking at your Google Street view there appears to be an error.  At the top of Nth King St at the junction of Bolton Street and Capel St. you can see the entrance to what they term "Henrietta Place" but is and as long as I know it Yarnhall St.  If you look in from Bolton St you can see the arched entrance to the old Linenhall Barracks/market which now leads to the DIT campus.  You can also see the vacant site of what was the "Bolton Horse" pub which was burned down many years ago and for which a number of people were jailed for arson!  It must be an old image because I think that that had been developed.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I find that I can speak French a lot better than I can write it and the nuances of grammar were the first to go!  You are probably the same, its called getting older;-))

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Yes, Google maps have clearly mislabelled Yarnhall street as Henrietta Place. The stonework in the arched entrance to the DIT certainly recalls the arches in the burnt out building above.

comment.author: 44274283@N07
comment._content: DIT Linenhall is now mostly occupied by the School of Architecture, and about a third of the building is School of Trades and Construction. The DIT Linenhall is the only surviving section of the Georgian linen hall, there's still arches visible in the building especially at the gate and lodge, though it's largely masked by the school's 1960's conversion into a school of trades. Judging by the angles, this view is probably from the back courtyard of the DIT Linenhall looking back towards the trading hall. I'll try and get a modern-day picture when I head into college later.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Looking at Nialls map the barracks/market was very strategically situated but would present a broad front to attacking troops.  The Bolton Street end did not command too much with the college on the far side providing a higher position for snipers.  It backed onto the park of the Kings Inns and there was also an entrance at Coleraine House at the top of Coleraine St.  This meant that any positions there were very vulnerable to being outflanked.  The decision to burn it probably rendered it unusable for a few days at least given its size and gave the rebels a certain amount of cover for their barricades at Church St - Nth King St.  I always understood that some reserve cavalry who had assembled at Linenhall had come under fire and had to withdraw hastily but I cannot find any reference to that at the moment and from the census returns it seems unlikely?

comment.author: 71822085@N03
comment._content: This photo appears in the 1966 Capuchin Annual with the following caption: Ruins of Linenhall barracks, which were then being used by the British authorities as the Army Pay Department, and which were destroyed by members of the Four Courts garrison. Paddy Holahan's description of its destruction from the same source: It had been ascertained that there were isolated enemy garrisons in the Bridewell and in the Linenhall Barracks, and it was decided to round them up. A party was detailed to capture the barracks. The garrison, which numbered some forty unarmed men of the Army Pay Corps were summoned to surrender, but refused. Gelignite was placed in position in the wall facing Lurgan Street, and the barracks’ door was burst open with sledge hammers. The garrison then surrendered. At the Bridewell a number of armed policemen, found in the cellars, were disarmed and brought into the Four Courts. At 3 p.m., Linenhall Barracks was set on fire to prevent its reoccupation by the encircling forces, and in the course of the day the blaze assumed large proportions. During Wednesday night it lighted up the streets with a murky glow. By Thursday it had travelled to Messrs. Moore’s, the druggists, in Bolton Street, and then became really spectacular. Large barrels of oil were tossed into the air and exploded, and a cloud of stifling smoke shrouded the district. Attempts were made to confine the fire by hosing, and these were partially successful. Even on Thursday night, the blaze made the streets bright as day, but by Friday it had subsided, and pitch darkness once more reigned at night. The remaining tenements in North King Street were hastily evacuated except by those whose grim business it was to stay there and fight to the death. Shops were hastily barricaded with corrugated iron and planking. ...Dinny O’Callaghan...was operating in the area and was responsible for the taking over and destruction of Linenhall Barracks.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/71822085@N03] Thanks so much for adding that vivid description! That 1966 issue is, unsurprisingly, the most requested of our run of the Capuchin Annual....
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
